Things haven\'t gone well lately, but I know tomorrow will be better
List your moods after doing this activity and rate them on a scale of 0–100.
When describing your situation, be as descriptive as possible. It\'s important to note your surroundings.
A few helpful questions you can ask yourself are:

1. Who was I with?
2. What was I doing?
3. When did it happen?
4. Where was I?

Include a specific time frame that does not exceed 30 minutes. For example, there are too many different situations, emotions, and thoughts that can occur \"all day Tuesday.\" A better description might be \"Tuesday at noon.\"
Good example:\n\"Friday morning at 8. Making coffee. Kids are getting ready for school. Husband is watching the news.\"
Bad example:\n"Friday before work. Very loud. Irritated at husband."

List the moods you were experiencing in the situation you described. It\'s natural to experience more than one mood in any situation. You should also rate the intensity of the moods on a scale of 0–100.
If you experience a lot of anxiety, it may be helpful to rate your physical symptoms as well.

Moods are more than simply feeling \"bad\" or \"good.\" They can also be easily confused with thoughts. As a rule of thumb, if you\'re describing a mood in more than one word, you should ask yourself whether it\'s really a mood, or more of a thought.

For example, you might feel tense and nervous and out of control, when the mood you\'re experiencing is anxiety. Or, you may feel hollow, numb and heavy when the mood you\'re experiencing is depression.
